bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, June 23, 1942

div1.p: Kellogg suggests that Hench give a lecture on yellow fever lecture in Philadelphia. He introduces his brother, a surgeon, and comments on the successful Cornwell painting unveiling at which Col. Rankin spoke.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, June 23, 1942

opener.dateline:
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N.J.
June 23, 1942.

div1.p:
(If you are shocked by the familiarity of
my address, bear in mind that you have brought it on your
own self.)

I have been planning to write to you ever
since Atlantic City, particularly to congratulate you on the
splendid set of slides which you have worked up for your
lecture. When the war is over if you want to go on tour
let me act as your business manager and booking agent and
I think we can go to town.

Seriously, if you are to be located in
Washington, I would like to arrange a lecture engagement
for you in Philadelphia, probably with the Philadelphia
Academy of Medicine. By making this arrangement you would
not only have a large audience of physicians but we could
arrange to have all of the Wyeth representatives who work
near Philadelphia present. I could not ask you to come to
Philadelphia just to lecture to our men but the combination
would yield quite an audience.

I just had word from my brother, Dr. Howard
B. Kellogg, in Seattle, that he is to get a Lieutenant
Colonel's commission in the base hospital corps which has
been organized in that city for some time. He will be in
charge of surgery. They expect to be called up most any
day. I presume that there are so many base hospital units
that any one is quite obscure in the Surgeon General's office,
but in the future, should your relations with such corps ever
bring the name of Dr. Howard B. Kellogg to your attention, I
would like to have you remember the connection.

I did not have an opportunity to tell you
after the luncheon at the Traymore that I give you a large
percentage of credit for our acquiring Col. Rankin as speaker
for the occasion. I saw the Colonel Friday morning just
before I left and he seemed to be in a good mood and felt
that he had had a good party. I was much pleased with this
as I felt that he might be somewhat resentful at having to
take the time for this ceremony when he was so busy with
other matters, but he didn't seem to feel that way at all.

Both Doris and I enjoyed the dinner very much
and please give my kindest regards to Mrs. Hench.
You may expect to see me in Washington before the
end of the summer.
div1.closer:
Sincerely, George A. Kellogg Philip S. Hench, M.D.
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester
Minnesota
P. S.
Attached find a copy of a letter addressed
to one of our detail supervisors from a representative
in Omaha. Just how much of a part Dr. Pinto played in
the Yellow Fever Investigation I don't know, but if you
are not in touch with him you will welcome getting his
address.
GAK:L
G. A.K.
